definition: seal script used throughout the pre-Han period
surname Zhou
(writing)/to develop/seal script used throughout the pre-Han period
abbr. for 書經|书经[Shu1 jing1]
book/letter/document/CL:本[ben3],冊|册[ce4],部[bu4]/to write
seal script used throughout the pre-Han period
the great seal/used narrowly for 籀文/used broadly for many pre-Qin scripts
early form of Chinese characters inscribed in stone, a precursor of the small seal 小篆[xiao3 zhuan4]
the small or lesser seal, the form of Chinese character standardized by the Qin dynasty
seal script as unified by the Qin dynasty/the small seal 小篆 and great seal 大篆
Shizhoupian, early school primer in great seal script 大篆[da4 zhuan4], attributed to King Xuan of Zhou 周宣王[Zhou1 Xuan1 wang2] but probably dating from c. 500 BC
Xiping steles, calligraphic work on carved steles of the Eastern Han Dynasty (25-220 AD)
inscription in bronze/bell-cauldron inscription
clerical script/official script (Chinese calligraphic style)

Six Methods of forming Chinese characters, according to Han dictionary Shuowen 說文|说文 - namely, two primary methods: 象形 (pictogram), 指事 (ideogram), two compound methods: 會意|会意 (combined ideogram), 形聲|形声 (ideogram plus phonetic), and two transfer methods: 假借 (loan), 轉注|转注 (transfer)
calligraphic style/font
bird writing, a calligraphic style based on seal script 篆书, but with characters decorated as birds and insects
to explain/to interpret/interpretation
grass script/cursive script (Chinese calligraphic style)
character book (i.e. school primer)
see 說文解字|说文解字[Shuo1 wen2 Jie3 zi4]
